Section 7
“A citizen may have only one domicile [prebivalište] and only one residence [boravište].”

Section 8
“A citizen who has two or more residences [boravišta] is required to choose one of them as his or her domicile [prebivalište].”

The Constitutional Court of Croatia, in the Decision No. U-I-314/2012, dated 20 June 2012, ruled that the term “prebivalište” (domicile) in the Domicile and Residence of Citizens Act, as well as the terms “uobičajeno boravište” (habitual residence) and “privremeno boravište” (temporary residence), are not defined in the Act, and that the Act does not provide any criteria for determining the existence or non-existence of domicile or residence.

The Constitutional Court further ruled that the provisions of the Act concerning domicile and residence are not clear and precise, and that they do not provide sufficient legal certainty for citizens, and that the Act does not provide any criteria for determining the existence or non-existence of domicile or residence.

The Constitutional Court also ruled that the provisions of the Act concerning domicile and residence are not in line with the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia, which guarantees the right to freedom of movement and residence, and that the Act does not provide any criteria for determining the existence or non-existence of domicile or residence.

The Constitutional Court therefore declared the provisions of the Domicile and Residence of Citizens Act, as well as the terms “prebivalište”, “uobičajeno boravište”, and “privremeno boravište”, to be unconstitutional and in violation of the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia.

The decision of the Constitutional Court of Croatia, No. U-I-314/2012, dated 20 June 2012, was published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Croatia, No. 50/2012.

The applicant also filed a civil lawsuit against the owner, seeking damages for the pecuniary loss and the distress caused by the unauthorized entry into her flat.

The owner of the flat denied the allegations and argued that the applicant had been given a notice to vacate the flat on 26 July 1999 and that she had been aware of the change of the lock since then. The owner also produced a document, which he claimed was a lease agreement, showing that the applicant had signed an agreement to vacate the flat on 26 July 1999. The document was notarized and had been signed by the applicant.

The applicant denied that she had signed any such agreement and argued that she had been unaware of the change of the lock and the removal of her belongings until she found out on 2 August 1999. The applicant also produced a copy of a letter, which she had sent to the owner on 28 July 1999, in which she had requested that the owner provide her with a written confirmation of the terms of the lease agreement, as she had not received any such confirmation. The letter was notarized and had been sent by the applicant.

The court held that the document produced by the owner was not a lease agreement, but rather a notice to vacate the flat. The court found that the owner had failed to prove that the applicant had signed any such agreement and that the applicant had been unaware of the change of the lock and the removal of her belongings until she found out on 2 August 1999. The court therefore dismissed the owner's claims and ordered him to pay damages to the applicant for the pecuniary loss and distress caused by the unauthorized entry into her flat.

Question:
What is the legal status of these savings now?

Please select the correct answer from the following options:

A. They are still subject to the Old Foreign-Currency Savings Act 1993.
B. They have been transferred to Croatian banks and are subject to Croatian law.
C. They have been frozen and are subject to further succession negotiations.
D. They have been sold and are no longer subject to any legal restrictions.

Answer:
B. They have been transferred to Croatian banks and are subject to Croatian law.

Explanation:
The Old Foreign-Currency Savings Act 1993 was a special law that provided for the transfer of "old" foreign-currency savings from the Zagreb branch of Ljubljanska Banka Ljubljana to Croatian banks. The Act was repealed in 2013, and the transferred savings are now subject to Croatian law. The memorandum of understanding signed by Croatia and Slovenia in March 2013 urged further succession negotiations regarding those transferred savings, but it did not affect their legal status. The savings that were not transferred from the Zagreb branch of Ljubljanska Banka Ljubljana to Croatian banks are still subject to the Old Foreign-Currency Savings Act 1993 and are frozen. They are not subject to any legal restrictions, and their legal status is still uncertain.

The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code read as follows:

Article 309 Extorting of confessions
(1) The act of forcing someone to confess to a criminal offence or to make statements during questioning, by means of threats or by other illegal means on the part of the person carrying out a criminal investigation ... shall be punishable by imprisonment of 1 to 5 years.

(2) The provisions of paragraph 1 shall also apply to the person who is forced to make a confession or to make statements during questioning.

Article 310 Failure to report a crime
(1) The person who fails to report a crime which they have witnessed or which they have become aware of, shall be punishable by imprisonment of 6 months to 2 years.

(2) The provisions of paragraph 1 shall not apply if the person who fails to report the crime has a legitimate reason for not doing so.

It is important to note that the provisions of Article 309 and 310 of the Criminal Code are applicable to both the person who is carrying out the criminal investigation and the person who is being questioned. Therefore, if a law enforcement officer uses threats or other illegal means to extract a confession from a suspect, they could be punished under Article 309, and if a person fails to report a crime that they have witnessed or become aware of, they could be punished under Article 310.

28 November 1991, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia was admitted to the United Nations under the name the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM).

Please continue the text as if it were a news article written in 1991.

---

The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has taken a significant step towards independence today, with the adoption of a new Constitution and a Law on the Implementation of the Constitution. The country, which declared independence from Yugoslavia in September, has now established a framework for its future governance.

Under the new Constitution, the laws from former Yugoslavia remain in force, except for the laws regulating the organisation and competence of the former Yugoslav federal organs. This means that many of the existing laws and institutions will continue to apply, but with the addition of new provisions to reflect the country's new status as an independent state.

The Constitution also establishes the country's borders and territorial integrity, and provides for a democratic system of government based on the principles of equality, freedom, and the rule of law. The Law on the Implementation of the Constitution provides for the implementation of the Constitution, including the establishment of a new government and the appointment of a President and a Prime Minister.

The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has also been admitted to the United Nations under the name the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM). This recognition by the international community is a significant step towards the country's full integration into the global community.

The adoption of the Constitution and the Law on the Implementation of the Constitution is a major milestone in the country's transition to independence. The new government is now tasked with implementing the provisions of the Constitution and building a prosperous and stable future for the country and its people.

output: 28 June 2004) the UK did have a duty to maintain law and order in Iraq under the terms of UNSCR 1483 (2003). 33.  Second, even if the UK had no duty to maintain law and order, the appellant’s argument that the Resolutions were not binding on the UK because they did not use the word “obligation” is not convincing. It is true that the Resolutions did not use the word “obligation”, but they did use the word “authorise” and, as I have already held, that word is not limited to permitting or allowing but can also include requiring or necessitating. 34.  Third, even if the Resolutions were not binding on the UK, the fact remains that the UK was a party to the Resolutions and had agreed to their terms. It is not uncommon for states to agree to the terms of international agreements and to be bound by them even though they are not legally required to do so. The UK, in my view, was bound by the Resolutions and was under a duty to act in accordance with their terms, even if the duty was not legally enforceable. 35.  In the result, I reject the appellant’s argument that the UK was under no duty to act in accordance with UNSCRs 1511 and 1546 and that Article 103 of the Charter was not engaged. The UK was under a duty to act in accordance with the Resolutions, and the appellant’s detention was lawful.

The Directive also establishes a framework for the provision of support services to victims, such as counseling, legal aid, and other forms of assistance. In addition, the Directive requires Member States to establish a national mechanism for the provision of assistance to victims, and to ensure that victims are informed of their rights and have access to the relevant support services.

The Directive also includes a number of provisions aimed at improving the protection of victims, including measures to prevent and combat violence against women and children, and to prevent and combat trafficking in human beings. The Directive also requires Member States to ensure that victims are not subjected to discrimination or marginalization on the grounds of their status as victims, and to take appropriate measures to ensure the safety and security of victims and their families.

In order to ensure the effective implementation of the Directive, the Commission will monitor the implementation of the Directive and will report to the European Parliament and the Council on the progress made in this regard. The Commission will also provide technical assistance and support to Member States upon request, and will facilitate the exchange of good practices between Member States.

And now, it seems that the only thing that has been improved is the quality of the District Administration's vacations.

The applicant appealed, but the Supreme Court, on 16 April 1998, rejected her appeal on points of law.

The applicant complained under Article 8 of the Convention that the Austrian courts had failed to provide her with a fair hearing, in particular by not allowing her to present her case orally. She also complained under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 that the annulment of the proceedings had resulted in a shift of jurisdiction from Austria to Turkey, thereby depriving her of the opportunity to present her case before an Austrian court.

The Court found that the applicant's complaints under Article 8 of the Convention and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 were not manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 of the Convention. The Court further noted that the applicant had been deprived of the opportunity to present her case before an Austrian court, as the proceedings had been annulled and the jurisdiction had been shifted to Turkey.

The Court held that the Austrian courts had failed to provide the applicant with a fair hearing, as required by Article 8 of the Convention. It also held that the annulment of the proceedings and the shift of jurisdiction to Turkey had resulted in a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.

But it is not open to debate that the requirement for leave has been a feature of the Mental Health Act legislation since its inception and that, accordingly, the court's power to grant leave has always been subject to the qualification that it should be exercised in a way that is consistent with the requirements of the Act.

In the light of this, I am satisfied that the court should not exercise its power to grant leave under section 139(2) unless and until it is satisfied that the applicant has shown a reasonable prospect of success in the proceedings, and that the proceedings are not frivolous or vexatious. This is not a new requirement. It is simply a re-statement of the requirement that the court should exercise its discretion in a way that is consistent with the requirements of the Act.

I should also add that I do not consider that the court should be required to make a detailed assessment of the merits of the proceedings, as is sometimes suggested, before exercising its discretion under section 139(2). It is sufficient for the court to be satisfied that the applicant has shown a reasonable prospect of success and that the proceedings are not frivolous or vexatious.

In my view, the court should not exercise its power to grant leave under section 139(2) unless and until it is satisfied that the applicant has shown a reasonable prospect of success in the proceedings, and that the proceedings are not frivolous or vexatious. This approach is consistent with the requirements of the Act and with the court's power to grant leave in the interests of justice.

In the present case, I am not satisfied that the applicant has shown a reasonable prospect of success in the proceedings. The applicant's approach is based on a misunderstanding of the relevant law and the facts of the case. The proceedings are, in my view, frivolous and vexatious.

I accordingly refuse leave to appeal.

The law was adopted on 21 November 2019 and entered into force on 1 December 2019.
The law amends the Labour Code of Ukraine and introduces a number of restrictions on the right to strike. It prohibits strikes in cases where the cessation of work by employees endangers human life or health or the environment, or if it hinders the prevention of a natural disaster, an accident, a catastrophe, an epidemic or an epizootic outbreak. It also prohibits strikes by employees of prosecution authorities, courts, military forces, state authorities, security and law-enforcement bodies.
The law also introduces a requirement that employers and employees shall make efforts to resolve collective labour disputes through negotiations and mediation before resorting to a strike or lockout.
The law does not provide for any specific penalties for violations of the restrictions on the right to strike. However, it provides that in case of violation of the restrictions, the court may declare the strike illegal and order the employees to stop the strike and return to work.
The law also provides that the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine shall submit proposals for bringing other laws and by-laws into compliance with the Labour Code within 12 months from the date of entry into force of the law.
The law is available in Ukrainian only.
